chunks.title: Section 120B IPC - Punishment for Criminal Conspiracy
chunks.content: Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term of two years or upwards, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had abetted such offence.
chunks.summary: Defines punishment for conspiracy to commit serious offences.

chunks.title: Nature of Offence
chunks.content: The offence under Section 120B IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.
chunks.summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.

chunks.title: Bailability
chunks.content: Section 120B IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

chunks.title: Trial Jurisdiction
chunks.content: Due to seriousness, Section 120B IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

chunks.title: Witness Testimony
chunks.content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.
chunks.summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.

chunks.title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
chunks.content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause of death, or identity of accused.
chunks.summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.

chunks.title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
chunks.content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) together to establish liability.
chunks.summary: Both mental and physical elements required.

chunks.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Som Nath Thapa
Kehar Singh v. State (Indira Gandhi Assassination)
chunks.ratio: Conspiracy may be proved by circumstantial evidence.

chunks.question: What is the punishment under Section 120B IPC?
chunks.answer: Punishment includes imprisonment and/or fine as provided by law.

chunks.question: Is Section 120B a bailable offence?
chunks.answer: No, it is generally non-bailable.

chunks.question: Is Section 120B a cognizable offence?
chunks.answer: Yes, police may register FIR and investigate without magistrate approval.

chunks.question: What is criminal conspiracy under Section 120A IPC?
chunks.answer: Criminal conspiracy means an agreement between two or more persons to commit an illegal act or a legal act by illegal means.

chunks.question: Can mere agreement amount to criminal conspiracy under Section 120B?
chunks.answer: Yes, the act of agreeing itself constitutes criminal conspiracy even if no further act is done.

chunks.question: Is criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC compoundable?
chunks.answer: No, conspiracy cases are not compoundable under law.

chunks.question: Which court tries offences under Section 120B IPC?
chunks.answer: Session Courts generally try serious conspiracy cases, while Magistrate courts can try minor ones.

chunks.question: Is intention required for conviction under Section 120B IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, intention to commit an illegal act is necessary for conviction.

chunks.question: Can a minor be prosecuted for criminal conspiracy?
chunks.answer: Yes, but if under 18, proceedings are under the Juvenile Justice Act.

chunks.question: Can abetment of criminal conspiracy be punished?
chunks.answer: Yes, abetment is punishable under Sections 109/120B IPC.

chunks.question: Is medical evidence required in criminal conspiracy cases?
chunks.answer: Medical evidence is not usually relevant unless the illegal act involves bodily harm.

chunks.question: Can conviction under Section 120B IPC be appealed?
chunks.answer: Yes, the convicted individual may appeal in higher courts.

chunks.question: Does conviction under Section 120B IPC affect government employment?
chunks.answer: Conviction for conspiracy may bar an individual from government service.

chunks.question: Are companies or firms liable under Section 120B IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, corporate entities can be held liable for criminal conspiracy if employees/directors are involved.

chunks.question: Are criminal conspiracy cases triable without evidence of overt act?
chunks.answer: Yes, even without an overt act, evidence of agreement is sufficient for prosecution.

chunks.question: What common defences exist against criminal conspiracy charges?
chunks.answer: Common defences include absence of agreement, lack of intention, or absence of illegal object.

chunks.question: Is there any limitation period for trial under Section 120B IPC?
chunks.answer: Generally, there is no limitation for serious conspiracy offences.

chunks.question: Are conspiracy cases under Section 120B IPC compoundable if parties settle?
chunks.answer: No, criminal conspiracy cases are non-compoundable and prosecuted even if parties settle.

chunks.question: What recent trends are seen in criminal conspiracy cases under IPC?
chunks.answer: Recent trends include use of electronic communications as evidence and involvement of corporate entities.

chunks.question: Is FIR necessary to begin criminal conspiracy prosecution?
chunks.answer: FIR is generally required to initiate investigation in criminal conspiracy offences under IPC.
